metadata.sermon_start_end: Do you have any family secrets? Most families do. In fact, I think all families do. There was a sister who was an alcoholic, a great-grandfather who served time for tax fraud, an uncle who committed suicide, an ancestor who had a slave mistress. Families don’t treasure stories about [...] No matter who you are or what you have done, he is calling you to himself and adorning you with his resurrection life. No one will ever be able to despise you or discredit you or discount you, because he has taken all the discounting and discrediting and despising unto himself. Now you are free, free to go forth and strengthen your brothers and sisters. He has paid the price and won the victory. The Lord is risen indeed! Alleluia!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first thesis by using a composite of texts (Luke, Matthew, Mark, Psalms, Romans, 1 Peter) rather than a single pericope. It treats 'the story of Peter' as a general biblical idea rather than exposing what is unique to one specific passage. It lacks the 'NOWHERE else' specificity Dekker demands.
quotes: Tonight we are going to ask ourselves why the church preserved and retold a terrible story about the apostle Peter.
This is what St. Mark says...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Limit the sermon to one specific pericope (e.g., only Luke 22:54-62) and excavate the unique theological contribution of that specific author's phrasing (like the 'look' in Luke) without diluting it with other versions.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: While there is a brief mention of Greek translation ('even Peter'), the sermon lacks deep engagement with the original context, Hebrew/Greek nuances, or the specific theology of the Lucan or Markan books. It functions more as a narrative retelling than a scholarly exposition.
quotes: Interpreters of Mark’s Gospel say that we can translate the Greek to read, 'even Peter!'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate more rigorous exegesis of the specific Greek terms used for 'turned' or 'looked' to reveal the historical-theological weight of the moment.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding human failure (divorce, tax fraud, alcoholism), which aligns with Dekker's requirement for 'true truth' being concrete. However, it occasionally drifts into general categories of 'people who have said...'.
quotes: Think of all the people who have said, 'For better, for worse...'; they meant it at the time, but half of them are now divorced.
I would never lie, steal, eavesdrop, hit and run, cheat on an exam...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the application more directly to the specific 'zeitgeist' or the immediate congregational reality rather than a list of general moral failures.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully avoids the '15 min exposition / 5 min application' trap. It moves fluidly between the biblical narrative and the hearer's reality, drawing the hearer into Peter's experience as their own.
quotes: Have you ever disgraced yourself like that? Of course you have; we all have.
Peter tried to hide, but the Lord found him with that look... Before God, there is no place to hide.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'recreation' of the Word (Thesis 1) is even more current, so the text is not just a mirror for the past but a 'proclamatory word' for the now.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon deals honestly with 'misery' (Peter as a 'total fraud', 'cowardice') and 'redemption' (rectification through Christ). It avoids 'soft' misery and focuses on man's state before God.
quotes: In that moment, the abject failure of the human creature was met by the penetrating gaze of the One...
Peter has nowhere left to stand in all the world.
Now you are free... to go forth and strengthen your brothers and sisters.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' section (the third part) could be more robustly developed as a response to the specific grace received.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the 'wrath of God' and the possibility of being 'discredited', which touches on the seriousness of the 'two ways'. However, the ultimate 'lostness' is somewhat softened by an emphasis on inevitable restoration.
quotes: God’s judgment fell upon Peter at that moment. But Jesus’ look is not a look of pure judgment.
Maybe you don’t want to hear about the wrath of God... but if you don’t know anything about the wrath of God, then the full dimensions of the Resurrection will be lost to you.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Make the 'temporal loss' or 'eternal loss' more explicit as a real possibility for the hearer, rather than just a theological backdrop for Peter.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes that salvation is outside of man ('rectified by his blood'). It upholds the necessity of Christ's divinity and intercession.
quotes: Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life.
He has taken all the discounting and discrediting and despising unto himself.
Christ the Lord is interceding for you.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the Christology is derived strictly from the specific text's portrayal of Him rather than importing a general Pauline 'justification' framework into a Gospel narrative.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes (1850 words), the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. According to Dekker, 'depth needs breadth', and this sermon risks being too concise for the weight of the subject.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical depth (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-minute threshold, allowing the 'specific truth' of the passage more room to breathe.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails fundamentally on Dekker's first requirement: it is not an exposition of a *specific* Bible passage, but a thematic synthesis of the 'Peter story' across multiple books. It lacks the required length (under 20 minutes) for true depth. However, it is strong in its psychological honesty regarding human misery and its clear Christocentric focus on grace and rectification.
strengths: Concrete and unsparing description of human misery and failure.
Strong interwovenness of text and hearer's life.
Clear focus on Christ as the external source of salvation (Extra Nos).
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific pericope; too much 'harmonization' of different Gospels.
Insufficient length to achieve the 'breadth' required for theological depth.
The 'two ways' (the possibility of being lost) is present but lacks the sharp urgency Dekker demands.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an effective 'speech about a biblical character' but, according to Thesis 1.3, it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict sense. To become one, it must sacrifice its broad narrative scope for the depth of a single, specific text.
